awd_titl_txt: RUI:AAG: A Holistic Search for Megamaser Disks and their Role in Feeding Black Holes in the Nearby Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
 
Despite sustained and extensive searches for luminous emission from masers (the microwave version of the lasers) produced by water molecules in galaxy centers, their detection remains a mere 3%.   These systems, when found in a disk-like configuration, provide the most precise and accurate tools for weighing supermassive black holes, as well as unique constraints on the geometry of the universe because they can be used to directly determine extragalactic distances.  The aim of this project is a comprehensive investigation of the relationship between cosmic water maser activity and the properties of their host galaxies, which is imperative for assessing the true chances of finding more of these golden standards.   Maser disks are uniquely able to probe physical processes in the centers of galaxies, such as black hole accretion processes.  This should improve astronomer's knowledge of black hole demographics in active galaxies, and the inter-relationship between accretion, star-formation and other issues. 

Part 2
 
The investigation will consist of a complex multi-parameter analysis of various measures of the nuclear water maser emission and an extensive suite of optical, infrared, and X-ray characteristics of their host galaxies, their nuclear activity, as well as their small-scale environments and morphologies.  The statistics necessary to perform this study are only now available via multi-wavelength public databases, making possible to analyze the largest sample of galaxies found to date to host water masers, in comparison with galaxies in which maser detection failed.  Well-defined projects are designed to address key scientific questions on the potential links between the physics of water maser emission and the age, presence, absence, type, strength, and obscuration of the nuclear star-formation and galactic black hole accretion.   This study will offer unprecedented holistic constraints to the degree to which the strength and spatial configuration of water maser emission are linked to the associated nuclear galactic activity and host properties, thus providing the most efficient criteria for future disk-maser searches. 

Undergraduate students will be actively involved in the proposed research by performing data mining, image and spectral processing, designing and testing of a large variety of statistical analysis methods, participating in obtaining new observations and networking with scientists at national observatories.  Deaf and hard-of-hearing undergraduates will be included in each summer research session, and a pre-major internship for women will be implemented yearly in the existing recruiting and retaining program.   A novel grass-roots public outreach program will be established to literally take Astronomy to the Market, via a "scientific corner" where the PI and a team of undergraduates will offer hands-on science-driven activities along with safe solar observations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project produced the first comprehensive quantitative investigation of the degree to which the microwave amplification by stimulated emission radiation (maser) from water molecules, that is detected in galaxy centers, links with various properties of galaxies observed in the nearby universe, with emphasis on identifying more efficiently the edge-on maser disks that have the unique powers to: i) most accurately measure masses of supermassive black holes, ii) probe the small-scale structure and kinematics of accretion disks and surrounding dusty material in galaxy nuclei, as well as iii) independently measure the Hubble Constant as a needed constraint on the nature of dark energy.
We have explored a wealth of statistical comparative analysis techniques that have been designed and implemented in linking the maser emission from galaxy centers at levels that are millions of times (i.e., mega) brighter than similar emission found in star-forming regions in our Galaxy, with other types of electromagnetic radiation that are significantly more widely available for characterizing the traits of galaxies; the main goal is finding what types of galaxies are more prone to the megamaser disk emission activity, and therefore find ways of identifying them more efficiently for future surveys, as well as understanding the nature of this particular emission in the context of galaxy formation and evolution processes. 
Two main efforts have been emphasized here: 1) machine learning techniques like the Principal Component Analysis, Neural Networks, and more specialized Random Forest procedures for researching ways to counter the impact of the imbalanced nature of data on models for classifying maser galaxies from large samples of objects based on properties measured in other wavelengths; 2) mid-infrared overall emission and variability based on observations from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer to quantify the degree to which emission and properties of radiation from actively accreting supermassive black holes in galaxy centers (i.e., Active Galactic Nuclei, or AGNs) occur in conjunction to the water megamaser emission, via novel diagnostics of identifying elusive AGNs that are missed in traditional methods, as well as original ways of exploring the potential reprocessing of their radiation by circumnuclear cosmic dust.
Our results reveal new ways of connecting the AGN phenomenon with the water megamaser emission.  We found that during the 10-year of variability data studied here galaxies of all types are missed as being classified as AGNs based on their mid-IR colors for about 20% of the time, which means there is a significant fraction of blue galaxies that are in fact hidden AGNs, among both maser and non-maser galaxies, thus revealing novel ways of searching for potential megamaser disks, as well as new constraints for the true fraction of megamaser emission among various types of galaxies as classified based on various mutliwavelength techniques. We demonstrate that by incorporating hard X-ray information in the analysis of the parameters that relate most efficiently with the high detection rates of maser galaxies, and by performing multiwavelength spectral fitting to minimize the impact of the host galaxy emission on mid-IR measurements of the host galaxy emission associated with the water maser activity, we can dramatically enhance the efficiency with which we can discover new megamaser disk systems.  Via machine learning techniques we show that it is possible to predict water maser detections with >70% probability with a detection rate of > 40%, which is a factor of ten increase from all previous attempts.  We have been awarded 23 new hours of survey observing with the Green Bank Telescope, for observations that confirmed eight new megamaser detections along with three more tentative, for an overall detection rate of > 14%, a several-fold increase relative to the current surveys.
This project integrated the active participation of a large and particularly diverse body of undergraduate and high-school students into cutting-edge astrophysics research, along with the implementation of an energetic grass-roots outreach program that literally takes astronomy to the market.  Intense efforts focused on recruiting summer students among the hard-of-hearing or deaf students from Gallaudet University, as well as among incoming students who are traditionally underrepresented in physics and astronomy (women, African Americans, Latinx, Asians/pacific islanders, low-income, first-generation college students) have been significantly hindered by the lingering effects of the COVID-19 pandemic; we have been successful in actively involving in research projects a total of eight undergraduates and three high school students, one of them as an incoming physics major to JMU.  They have been trained in manipulating large data sets, coding in Python, IDL, and SQL, reading and comprehending scientific literature on the AGN physics and their link to the maser emission in galaxy centers, in presenting their work to (local, national, and international) conferences, and co-authoring peer-review publications.   There have been numerous awards for the work presented by the students.  The PI developed new collaborations with scientists from the Statistics and Computer Science departments at JMU.
